speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.2: High School Renovation Project - The board will consider approval of funding for major facility improvements at the high school, including building four new science laboratories and repairing the athletic fields. The science lab construction is projected to cost $1,240,400 spread over four years, while athletic field repairs are included in the same package. These upgrades aim to improve STEM instruction and student access to safe extracurricular facilities.. Who would like to start?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thank you, Graham. Just a quick point of order, I'd love it if we could get some more information on exactly what these athletic field repairs entail. Is that something that we can have presented? I've had a lot of concerns expressed to me about the safety of our athletic facilities, so just making sure those are being thoroughly addressed.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Right. Ms. Osborne, maybe you could give us some details on the scope of work that's anticipated?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Absolutely, Graham. Yes, Katrína, I understand your concern about the athletic field repairs. According to the proposal, the repairs would involve resurfacing the track, replacing the turf, and addressing drainage issues to prevent flooding. Additionally, they'll be installing new goalposts, renovating the bleachers, and improving lighting for evening events. We can definitely provide more detailed information on the scope of work if needed. Do you think that addresses your concerns, Katrína?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yeah, thank you, Ellen. That does help clarify things a bit. I'm still wondering though if there's been any thought given to kind of looking at some of the other facilities on campus that are used for athletics, maybe beyond just the main football field and the track. You know, like the softball and baseball fields, tennis courts – because I've gotten complaints about those too. So I guess my question would be, has there been any consideration of a comprehensive look at all the athletic facilities on campus or is this really just focused on the main stadium area?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: That's a great point, Katrína. I think we do need to take a holistic view of our athletic facilities. While the current proposal focuses on the main stadium area, I believe it's essential we consider a master plan for all athletic facilities on campus. Perhaps we could explore phasing in renovations for the other areas you mentioned, like the softball and baseball fields, tennis courts, and others. Would it be possible, Graham, to request a feasibility study or a comprehensive assessment of all our athletic facilities to identify priorities and potential timelines for renovation?

speaker: grahampaige
content: That sounds like a very reasonable suggestion, Ms. Osborne. And would that be something that Dr. McLaughlin could add to the agenda for perhaps our October planning session?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Exactly, Graham! I think that would be a perfect fit for our October planning session. Dr. McLaughlin, could you confirm that you're able to add that to the agenda? And perhaps we could also invite some representatives from our athletic department and coaching staff to provide input on their specific needs and concerns. That way, we can get a well-rounded understanding of what's required to bring all our athletic facilities up to par.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Sorry, I just want to chime in real quick. I completely agree with Katrína and Ellen's points about taking a more comprehensive approach to our athletic facilities. As we move forward with these renovations, I think it's essential we prioritize STEM instruction and student safety. Could we get some clarification on how these new science labs will directly benefit our students and enhance their learning experience? Are there any plans to incorporate project-based learning or opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration within these new spaces?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you, David. I appreciate your emphasis on STEM instruction and student safety. I do have a few questions regarding the new science laboratories. Have we considered incorporating flexible seating arrangements and technology integration to facilitate more interactive learning experiences? Additionally, will these new labs be designed with sustainability in mind, possibly incorporating green building features or energy-efficient systems? Finally, have we thought about providing professional development opportunities for our science teachers to effectively utilize these new spaces and integrate them into their curricula?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Kate, excellent questions, as always. I think it's fantastic that you're considering the long-term implications of these new labs. I'd love to hear Ellen's thoughts on whether those aspects were factored into the design and planning phase. Ellen, could you speak to those points, especially the professional development piece? How do we ensure our teachers are equipped to make the most of these new resources?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thank you, David and Kate, for your thoughtful questions. I'm happy to report that, yes, we did consider flexible seating arrangements and technology integration to promote interactive learning experiences. In fact, the design includes modular furniture, writable surfaces, and state-of-the-art audiovisual equipment to facilitate collaboration and experimentation.

Regarding sustainability, I'm pleased to say that the new labs will incorporate green building features, such as energy-efficient lighting and HVAC systems, to minimize our environmental footprint.

Now, about professional development opportunities for our science teachers... I completely agree that it's crucial we support our educators in effectively utilizing these new spaces. We plan to allocate funds for teacher training and workshops, specifically focused on integrating technology, project-based learning, and interdisciplinary collaboration into their curricula. This will ensure our teachers feel confident and prepared to leverage these new resources to enhance student learning outcomes.

Kate, would you like me to elaborate on the specifics of the professional development plan, such as the timeline and scope of the training sessions?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you, Ellen. That's reassuring to hear that flexibility, technology, and sustainability were considered in the design process. I would appreciate it if you could provide more details on the professional development plan, particularly the timeline and scope of the training sessions. Additionally, have we identified any potential partnerships or collaborations with local organizations, like the University of Virginia or the Blue Ridge Botanical Gardens, to further enrich our STEM programs and provide our students with hands-on learning experiences?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Absolutely, Kate. I'd be happy to provide more information on the professional development plan. We're planning to offer a series of workshops and training sessions over the course of the next academic year, starting with a summer institute for our science teachers. The sessions will focus on topics such as project-based learning, technology integration, and interdisciplinary collaboration. We'll also provide ongoing support throughout the year, including coaching and mentoring, to ensure our teachers feel comfortable and confident in their ability to implement these new approaches.

Regarding partnerships and collaborations, we've already had preliminary discussions with the University of Virginia's engineering department about potential opportunities for our students to participate in research projects and internships. We're also exploring possibilities with the Blue Ridge Botanical Gardens for outdoor classroom experiences and hands-on learning activities. Additionally, we're reaching out to local businesses and industries to establish mentorship programs and job shadowing opportunities for our students.

I think these partnerships will not only enrich our STEM programs but also provide our students with valuable real-world experiences and connections that can help inform their career choices. Judy, have you had a chance to reach out to any local businesses or organizations that might be interested in partnering with us?

speaker: judyle
content:
Thank you, Ellen. I appreciate the update on the professional development plan and partnership opportunities. Actually, I have been in touch with a few local organizations, including the Charlottesville-Albemarle Technical Education Center, about potential collaborations. They expressed interest in working with us to develop vocational training programs and apprenticeships for our students. I believe these types of partnerships can help bridge the gap between academics and industry, providing our students with practical skills and exposure to different career paths.

Moving forward, I'd like to suggest that we establish a clear framework for tracking the impact of these partnerships on student outcomes and program effectiveness. Perhaps we could develop key performance indicators to measure the success of these collaborations and use that data to refine our strategies moving forward. What are your thoughts on that, Ellen?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Judy, that's fantastic news about the interest from the Charlottesville-Albemarle Technical Education Center! Vocational training programs and apprenticeships can be incredibly valuable for our students.

And I couldn't agree more about establishing a clear framework for tracking the impact of these partnerships. Developing key performance indicators will allow us to assess the effectiveness of our collaborations and make data-driven decisions to improve our strategies. It's essential that we're able to measure the return on investment for these partnerships and ensure they're truly benefiting our students.

Graham, could you speak to how we might incorporate these metrics into our existing evaluation frameworks and reporting structures? Would it make sense to tie these KPIs to our overall strategic plan and goals for STEM education?

speaker: grahampaige
content:
Yes, absolutely, Ellen and Judy. Your suggestions align perfectly with our goals for evaluating program effectiveness and making data-informed decisions. We definitely should incorporate these metrics into our existing evaluation frameworks and reporting structures. And yes, tying these KPIs to our overall strategic plan and goals for STEM education would provide us with a clear direction and focus.

To answer your question, Judy, regarding establishing a clear framework for tracking the impact of these partnerships, perhaps we could task our analytics team with developing those key performance indicators. Then, as Ellen mentioned earlier, we could incorporate those metrics into our existing reporting structures to monitor progress toward our goals. By doing so, we would be able to assess the effectiveness of our partnerships and make adjustments accordingly.

I would like to express my sincere appreciation to both Ellen and Judy for their tireless efforts in advancing our STEM initiatives and seeking innovative ways to enrich our students' learning experiences. It is indeed through collaborative efforts like these that we can make a meaningful difference in our students' lives. Thank you both again for your dedication to our school division.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thank you, Graham, for your kind words and for outlining a clear plan for incorporating these metrics into our evaluation frameworks. I completely agree that our analytics team would be the perfect resource to develop these key performance indicators.

Before we move forward, I just want to ensure that we're considering the diversity of our student population and the varying needs of our learners. As we develop these metrics, let's make sure we're accounting for factors like socio-economic status, English language learner status, and special education requirements. We want to ensure that these partnerships are benefitting all students, not just a select few.

Ellen, could you speak to how we might build in safeguards to guarantee that our partnerships are equitable and accessible to all students? Maybe we could discuss potential strategies for outreach and engagement to ensure that underrepresented groups are aware of and have access to these opportunities?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thank you, Judy, for bringing up such a crucial point. Ensuring equity and accessibility is paramount in our partnerships and metrics. We must recognize that our student population is diverse, and we need to account for the various needs and circumstances of our learners.

Absolutely, as we develop these metrics, we should consider factors like socio-economic status, English language learner status, and special education requirements. This will enable us to identify areas where we need to provide additional support and resources to level the playing field.

To build in safeguards, I propose that we establish an advisory committee comprised of representatives from our diverse student populations, parents, teachers, and community organizations. This committee can provide feedback on our partnership strategies and metrics, helping us identify potential biases and areas for improvement.

In terms of outreach and engagement, we could utilize multiple channels to promote these opportunities, such as social media, parent-teacher organization meetings, and community events. We should also consider partnering with local organizations that serve underrepresented groups to help us reach and engage with these students.

Additionally, we might explore offering targeted support services, like mentorship programs or academic support centers, to help students from underrepresented groups navigate these opportunities and overcome any barriers they may face.

Kate, what are your thoughts on how we might integrate these equity considerations into our partnership agreements and contracts? Should we include specific language or clauses to ensure our partners are committed to serving all students equitably?

speaker: kateacuff
content:
Ah, excellent discussion, everyone. I'm really glad we're prioritizing equity and accessibility in our partnerships. To answer your question, Ellen, I think it's essential that we incorporate specific language into our partnership agreements and contracts to ensure our partners understand our commitment to serving all students equitably.

Perhaps we could include clauses related to demographic representation, culturally responsive programming, and targeted support services for underrepresented groups. Additionally, we might require our partners to provide regular reports on their outreach and engagement efforts, as well as the demographics of participants in their programs.

This way, we can hold ourselves and our partners accountable for promoting equity and addressing the needs of all students. What are your thoughts on that, Graham? Should we consult with our legal counsel to draft sample language for these agreements?

speaker: grahampaige
content:
Absolutely, Kate. I concur with your suggestion to incorporate specific language into our partnership agreements and contracts. It's vital that we hold ourselves and our partners accountable for promoting equity and addressing the needs of all students.

Yes, please, Kate, consult with our legal counsel to draft sample language for these agreements. Involving them early on will ensure that we're legally sound in our approach. Also, could we possibly invite some of our community partners who work closely with underrepresented groups to review the language and provide feedback before finalizing our partnership agreements?

Now, I'd like to pose a question to Mr. Alcaro. Could you give us an update on the current state of our Career and Technical Education programs and how they currently align with our proposed STEM initiative? Are there any potential synergies or opportunities for collaboration between these two areas?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content:
Thank you, Graham. That's a fantastic question. Our Career and Technical Education programs are quite strong, and we've seen significant growth in student participation over the past year. One area I'd love to see further alignment between CTE and STEM is in workforce development, particularly around apprenticeships and internships.

Can we tap into the expertise of our local businesses and industries to offer more experiential learning opportunities for our students? Perhaps we could explore creating career pathways in emerging fields like cybersecurity, biotechnology, or renewable energy.

How might our partnerships facilitate connections between industry professionals and our students, especially those from underrepresented groups? And would it be feasible to develop mentorship programs that pair industry mentors with students pursuing careers in these high-demand fields?

I believe that by leveraging our CTE programs and integrating them with our STEM initiatives, we can better prepare students for post-secondary success and address the skills gap in our regional workforce. Ellen, could you elaborate on how we might integrate these ideas into our partnership agreements and ensure our partners are committed to providing these opportunities for our students?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Jon, I couldn't agree more on the importance of aligning our CTE programs with our STEM initiatives. Experiential learning opportunities, apprenticeships, and internships can be game-changers for our students, especially those from underrepresented groups.

Regarding integration into our partnership agreements, I think we should consider adding language that specifically outlines the expectations for industry partnerships and mentorship programs. We could require our partners to commit to providing a certain number of internship or apprenticeship slots for our students, with a focus on recruiting and supporting students from underrepresented groups.

We might also explore incentivizing our partners to develop mentorship programs that pair industry professionals with our students. This could include providing funding or resources to support these programs or recognizing partners who demonstrate a strong commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion.

Kate, could you work with our legal counsel to draft language that incorporates these ideas into our partnership agreements? And, Judy, would it be possible to involve our CTE department in the review process to ensure that we're aligning our agreements with their existing programs and goals?

Graham, I'd like to circle back to your idea of inviting community partners to review our partnership agreements. Who did you have in mind, and how might we structure that review process to ensure we're getting valuable feedback from these organizations?

speaker: grahampaige
content:
Yes, great point, Ellen. Thank you for picking up on that thread again. The community partners I had in mind were organizations like the Charlottesville-Albemarle Technical Education Foundation, the Chamber of Commerce, and perhaps the Charlottesville Area Community Foundation. These organizations already have established relationships with local businesses and industries, so they could potentially connect us with industry partners willing to offer internships, apprenticeships, or mentorship opportunities.

To structure the review process, we could assemble a small working group consisting of our CTE department, representatives from these community organizations, and maybe a few stakeholders from our advisory committee. This working group could review the draft language and provide feedback on its feasibility, effectiveness, and potential impact on our students.

Their input would be invaluable in crafting partnership agreements that not only meet our equity goals but also resonate with our community partners and industry stakeholders. So, Judy, could you please take the lead in assembling this working group and facilitating the review process?

speaker: judyle
content:
I appreciate the suggestions, Graham. I'm happy to take the lead in assembling the working group and facilitating the review process. Before we proceed, however, I just want to clarify a couple of things.

Could you elaborate, Graham, on what kind of timeline we're looking at for assembling this working group and completing the review process? And would it be possible to invite some students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, to participate in the review process as well?

Also, I'd like to add that while we're focusing on incorporating equity language into our partnership agreements, we shouldn't lose sight of the importance of ensuring that our own internal processes and procedures are equitable and transparent. We need to model the behavior we expect from our partners, after all. Kate, could you speak to how we're doing in terms of reviewing and revising our own internal policies to ensure they align with our equity goals?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Excellent points, Judy. I completely agree that we need to model the behavior we expect from our partners. Kate, I'd love to hear an update on our internal policy reviews and revisions.

And regarding the timeline, Graham, I think it's essential we move expeditiously on assembling the working group and completing the review process. Could we aim to have the working group formed within the next three weeks, with a goal of receiving feedback and revising the partnership agreements within six to eight weeks?

Judy, I appreciate your suggestion to involve students from underrepresented groups in the review process. That's a great way to ensure their voices are heard and valued. Perhaps we could identify a few student ambassadors to join the working group, representing different grade levels and demographics. David, could you help facilitate the selection process and ensure that our student ambassadors are adequately prepared to contribute to the review process?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Thank you everyone for voting. After counting all the votes, we have 5 (public) / 7 (private) in favor, 0 (public) / 0 (private) against, and 2 (public) / 0 (private) abstaining.
